content: The "Child Poverty Reduction Act of 2017" establishes a Federal Interagency Working Group on Reducing Child Poverty within the Department of Health and Human Services to develop a national plan to reduce child poverty. The primary goal of the Working Group is to develop a national plan to reduce the number of children living in poverty in the United States by half within 10 years and to eliminate extreme poverty among children within the same timeframe. The Working Group aims to reduce the number of children in poverty in the US to zero within 20 years. They will consult the National Academy of Sciences for recommendations and research. The Working Group, established by the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017, aims to develop a national plan to address child poverty within 180 days. The plan includes goals such as understanding root causes, improving accessibility to anti-poverty programs, and eliminating disparate rates of child poverty. The Working Group aims to address child poverty by eliminating disparities based on various factors, improving access to quality jobs for individuals in poverty, connecting low-income children and families to education and job opportunities, and shifting federal anti-poverty programs towards helping families rise above poverty. The Working Group aims to address child poverty by studying its effects on health, education, and economic stability, updating measures of poverty to account for various aspects. The Working Group focuses on addressing child poverty by updating measures of poverty to evaluate the effectiveness of anti-poverty programs. The Working Group focuses on updating measures of poverty to evaluate anti-poverty programs. SEC. 4 outlines other duties. The Working Group, in addition to developing the national plan, monitors Federal activities related to child welfare and poverty. It also establishes guidelines and policies in consultation with various entities and government officials. The Working Group advises Federal agencies on administering child welfare and poverty programs, recommends resources for public awareness, and improves communication. The Working Group aims to improve communication and collaboration among Federal, State, and local governmental entities regarding child welfare and poverty programs. They also hold hearings to gather public feedback on personal experiences related to child poverty and anti-poverty programs. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Working Group must have at least 6 members who are officials from executive departments with a pay rate equal to or greater than level IV of the Executive Schedule. The group must include officials from specific executive departments and each member is appointed by the head of their respective department. The Working Group consists of at least 6 members from executive departments with a pay rate equal to or greater than level IV of the Executive Schedule. Each member is appointed for the life of the Working Group, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, a majority of members constitute a quorum, and the Chairperson is appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Meetings are held monthly during the initial 180-day period and subsequently as needed. After the initial 180-day period, the Working Group will meet every 6 months or as called by the Chairperson or majority of members. The Working Group shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson, who can appoint additional staff as needed to achieve the group's goals. The Director and staff are responsible for carrying out the duties of the Working Group. Reporting requirements are also outlined. The Chairperson must submit an annual report to Congress by September 30, detailing the activities and plans of the Federal Government related to child welfare and poverty. This report should include information on efficiency improvements, reductions in child poverty, decreased demand for social services, and resulting savings to the government. The annual report to Congress by the Chairperson must include details on the impact of efforts to reduce child poverty, state initiatives, and legislative recommendations. The report should also be made publicly available and include updates from federal agencies. The head of each relevant Federal agency must post an annual summary of plans, activities, and results related to the goals and duties of the Working Group on the agency's public website. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions include terms like "anti-poverty program" for initiatives aimed at lifting families out of poverty, "child" for individuals under 18, "deprivation" for lacking basic needs, and "disconnected youth" for unemployed individuals aged 16 to 25 not in school. The term "economic stability" refers to individuals or families having the means to cope with adverse events while maintaining a decent standard of living. "Extreme poverty" is when an individual or family's income is less than 50% of the official poverty threshold.
